keyTakeAways: Aaron Spencer, an Army veteran and farmer from Cabot, Arkansas, is running for sheriff in Lonoke County while awaiting trial for the 2024 shooting of Michael Fosler, a man accused of sexual offenses against Spencer’s underage daughter.
Spencer claims the shooting was justified as a protective measure due to system failures in law enforcement and the judicial system, which failed to protect his child.
The shooting occurred on October 20, 2024, when Spencer discovered his daughter missing and found her in a vehicle driven by Fosler, prompting a confrontation that ended with Spencer shooting Fosler.
Spencer is currently out on bond and has pleaded not guilty, with his attorneys asserting he acted within the law to protect his daughter from a predator.
Spencer is running as a Republican to replace Sheriff John Staley, a three-term incumbent, who arrested him in October 2024.
The Lonoke County Republican Committee, led by Jennifer Hopper, states that most residents do not object to Spencer’s candidacy and believe the shooting was justified.
Spencer’s legal and political campaign is raising questions about accountability, justice, and the role of law enforcement in rural communities.
The case has drawn attention to broader issues in rural Arkansas, including trust in local law enforcement and the balance between individual self-defense and legal prosecution.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Aaron Spencer, an Army veteran and farmer from Cabot, Arkansas, is running for sheriff in Lonoke County while awaiting trial for the 2024 shooting of Michael Fosler, a man accused of sexually assaulting his underage daughter. Spencer claims he acted in self-defense and to protect his child after law enforcement failed to intervene. His attorneys maintain he was within his legal rights, and public opinion in the county appears largely supportive. Spencer is running as a Republican to replace Sheriff John Staley, whose department arrested him in October 2024. The primary election is scheduled for March 2025, with the general election in November 2026. The case highlights tensions between individual self-defense and systemic accountability in rural American law enforcement.
title: Arkansas Man Accused of Killing Alleged Abuser Runs for Sheriff While on Bond
